Dear Ms. Shillings:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Cathrine Raftery, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 10/25/23, youth sustained a bloody nose as a result of being
restrained by staff member during a transport.
Investigation Interviews:
Director/Complaint Source was interviewed via phone on
October 31, 2023. Director reported a restraint occurred due to
Youth A attempting to AWOL from the facility and being a young year
of age. She reported she did not know the full story as she was not
there. Director reported Youth A disclosed this complaint to Chief
Administrator. She reported she attempted to talk to Youth A about
this and he refused to talk.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility
on November 2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS
Worker. Chief Administrator reported Youth B told him Youth A was
in a bad restraint with Supervisor. He reported he spoke with Youth A
about this concern. Chief Administrator reported Youth A disclosed
he had spit in Supervisor’s face and Supervisor smacked Youth A
which caused him to have a bloody nose. Youth A reported he had
gotten two bloody noses since being at the facility noting one was
from overheating and the other one was from getting hit by
Supervisor. Chief Administrator reported Youth B has changed his
story about what he saw in the restraint several times. He reported
Youth B did not see Supervisor hit Youth A. Chief Administrator
reported Youth A did not need any medical attention and had no
marks or bruises from the restraint. He reported he has had no
concerns with Supervisor’s ability to perform his job but due to the
allegations he was put on administrator leave pending the
investigation.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at his school on November
2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported
he has been at the facility for about a week and reported that he has
had a couple of nose bleeds. He stated he had his first nosebleed at
the facility because he was hot and the other one because he got hit
by Supervisor. Youth A reported Supervisor is a nice staff and is
good at his job. He reported the other day he had left the building
2

and the staff had to chase him. He reported another youth had
caught him and put him in the car. Youth A reported Supervisor had
restrained him in the car, and he was sitting on Supervisor’s lap in
the car. He stated he turned around and spit in Supervisor’s face.
Youth A reported this then caused Supervisor to hit him in the face
with a flat hand which caused his bloody nose.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
November 2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Supervisor reported he has a positive relationship with the youth at
the facility, including Youth A. Supervisor reported when he was
working on October 25, 2023, he received a phone call from Staff 1
stating she needed assistance because Youth A had run off.
Supervisor reported Youth A has had the history of attempting to run
into the street and wanting to get hit by a car to end his life. He
reported when he got to the correct street, Staff 1 was doing a
standing hold with Youth A. Supervisor reported he transitioned Staff
1 out of the hold, and he took over. He reported he guided Youth A
back to the car and maintained the hold to get him into the car.
Supervisor reported he maintained the hold because Youth A kept
trying to get out of the car and was trashing around the car. He
stated Youth A spit but he never hit Youth A. Supervisor reported
Youth A was sitting up the entire time. He reported the restraint was
all one hold as it went from standing then transitioned to seated in
the car. He reported while they were in the car he had just held both
of Youth A’s arms where he had both of Youth A’s arms behind his
back like the approved seated hold in CPI. Supervisor reported this
was done due to Youth A’s attempts of trying to jump out of a moving
vehicle. He reported everyone had seat belts on and Staff 1 was able
to buckle himself and Youth A in the car while he maintained the
hold. Supervisor reported when Youth A’s nose started to bleed, he
was released. He reported they gave Youth A some cold rags and
helped clean him up. Supervisor reported he didn’t put Youth A face
first into the car and Youth A had no cuts or bruises on him after the
restraint. Supervisor reported his job is to keep the youth safe. He
reported Youth A is a young youth and was attempting to AWOL
which is by a busy street where he could get hurt.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on November
2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported
he has been at the facility for about three weeks, and he gets along
with Youth A. Youth B reported he has never been restrained but did
see Youth A get restrained the other day. He reported he does not
know the name of the staff that were involved. He reported Youth A
was running away outside and a female staff told Youth B to grab
him to stop him from running and he did so. Youth B reported a male
staff was also there and that staff restrained Youth A and put him in
the car face down on the seat. He reported the male staff continued
3

to restrain Youth A when in the car as Youth A was sitting and having
his body twisted with his face on the seat. Youth B reported the male
staff had his body leaning on Youth A to keep him down. Youth B
reported he witnessed this all happen as he was sitting in the front
seat of the car and the female staff was driving them back to the
facility. Youth B reported everyone had seatbelt on in the car. He
reported he does not remember hearing the staff say anything but
does remember Youth A asking staff to get off of him. When they
arrived back at the facility, Youth A’s face was bleeding and staff
tried to say it was from the adrenaline. Youth B reported Youth A was
not bleeding before he got into the car. He reported the staff helped
clean up Youth A and took him to get food.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on November
2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported she
was working on October 25, 2023, and took Youth A and Youth B
outside. Youth A ran away from her, which he had done previously.
Staff 1 reported Youth A has the history of running off to unsafe area
and has threatened to run into the street to get hit by a car. She
reported she called Supervisor for support due to the concerns of
Youth A getting hit by a car. Staff 1 reported she had Youth A in line
of sight and told Youth B to go get Youth A because she was not fast
enough. She reported she was able to get a hold of Youth A and put
him in a small child restraint standing hold to keep him from
AWOLing with the potential risk of getting hit by a car. She stated
Supervisor came and switched out in the restraint with her and was
able to get him into the car. Staff 1 reported Supervisor kept Youth A
in a seated hold due to Youth A trying to get out of the car. She
reported the restraint hold was never released and she reported she
drove the car back to the facility. Staff 1 reported Supervisor had hold
of both of Youth A’s arms behind his back in an approved seated
hold. She reported Youth A’s body was kept straight up. She stated
that she assisted with buckling in Youth A’s seatbelt. Staff 1 reported
they were just a few streets down and she monitored through the
rearview mirror the hold that was occurring. She stated she never
saw Supervisor put Youth A’s head into the seat or hit him in the
face. Staff 1 reported she saw Supervisor keep him in a seated
control hold and angled his body so that he was still sitting up. She
reported when they got out of the car, Youth A’s nose was bleeding a
lot. Staff 1 reported she noticed Youth A's nose began to bleed a little
bit when she first did the standing hold. She stated when they got to
the facility, they cleaned up Youth A and he reported no concerns.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on
November 2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Therapist reported Youth A has a history of behavioral concerns and
suicidal ideation. She reported Youth A has attempted to run into
busy streets due to wanting to get hit by a car.
4

Documents Reviewed:
Facility Residential Incident report dated 10/25/2023 and
MiSACWIS Restraint Report 166000214- Restraint report was
completed for the restraint that occurred on 10/25/2023 and was
completed in a timely manner. The report noted, Staff 1 had called
for assistance as Youth A went AWOL from the facility into a busy
road. Prior to restraint, staff attempted to redirect the youth. Youth A
was placed in a child control position by Supervisor and Staff 1 and
was moved into a seated position when placed in the car for safety.
Youth A was placed in a seated position as he was trying to get out
of the car while the car was moving, and this hold lasted for 3 to 5
minutes. Youth A’s nose started to bleed in the car and noted he
appeared to be over heated. Once back to the building Youth A was
released immediately. Youth A was checked for injury and treated
with a cold compress to the back of client’s neck which his nose
stopped bleeding shortly after he cooled down.
Supervisor and Staff 1 Human Resource File and Training log-
Supervisor had one disciplinary action within his file which was due
to concerns of not completing the correct documentation when
leaving on an outing. Staff 1 had no disciplinary actions noted in her
file prior to this incident. Supervisor and Staff 1 completed their CPI
restraint training on both 2/16/23 and a refresher on 6/16/23.
Facility Employee Handbook- Staff are to never use physical
discipline to inflicted harm in any manner.
Facility Policy/Procedure for CPI in Residential Programing
dated 05/09/23- All staff are certified in Crisis Prevention Institute
(CPI), Non-Violent Crisis Intervention. The policy notes staff should
never go hands on with a youth as a form of punishment, discipline,
ensuring compliance, demonstrating authority, or retaliation. Staff
should only use a physical restraint to protect client or others from
unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places them at
serious threat of violent or injury if no immediate intervention occurs.
Youth A’s Facility Incident Reports since being placed at the
facility 10/13/23- Youth A has attempted or has run out of the
building towards the busy streets seven times since being placed at
the facility. There were three restraints due to the concerns of Youth
A not following redirection and putting him at serious harm of getting
hurt by a car.
CPI Manual- CPI manual was reviewed onsite showing the
approved seated restraint where a staff member to hold both of
the youth’s arms behind the youth’s back. The staff member then
has the youth seated up and lean their body into them.
5

Analysis The facility is found in compliance with performing the restraint
hold in a safe manner. There was no evidence to support that
Staff 1 had harmed Youth A to cause Youth A’s nose to bleed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (2) The following restraints are strictly prohibited:
(g )Peer-on-peer discipline or utilizing the assistance of another
youth to implement a restraint.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth B was told by Staff 1 to grab Youth A prior to a restraint
occurring.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at his school on November
2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported
when he was walking away from staff, Youth B was the one to stop
him before Staff 1 went into a restraint. Youth A reported Youth B
had grabbed both of his arms to stop him from running before Staff 1
caught up to him. He stated then Staff 1 held him in a restraint while
he was standing before Supervisor came.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on November
2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported
he has never been restrained but did see Youth A get restrained the
other day. He reported Youth A was running away outside and a
female staff told Youth B to grab him to stop him from running and he
did so. He reported he held both of Youth A’s arms briefly and then
the staff restrained him.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on November
2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported she
was working on October 25, 2023, and took Youth A and Youth B
outside. Youth A ran away from her, which he had done previously.
She reported she called Supervisor for support due to the concerns
of Youth A getting hit by a car. Staff 1 reported she had Youth A in
line of sight and told Youth B to go get Youth A because she was not
fast enough. She reported Youth B just put both of his hands on
Youth A’s shoulder to keep him from moving. Staff 1 reported she
was a few feet away and had eyes on the whole situation. She
reported she was able to get a hold of Youth A and put him in a small
child restraint standing hold to keep him from AWOLing with the
potential risk of getting hit by a car. She reported she knows she
should have not asked Youth B to hold onto Youth A but she did not
know what else to do to keep him safe. Staff 1 reported she has bad
knees and could not move as fast as Youth A was going.
6

Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
November 2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Supervisor reported staff are to never ask a youth to restrain or hold
onto another youth. He reported Staff 1 was already in the hold with
Youth A when he arrived.
Documents Reviewed:
Supervisor and Staff 1 Human Resource File and Training log-
Supervisor had one disciplinary action within his file which was due
to concerns of not completing the correct documentation when
leaving on an outing. Staff 1 had no disciplinary actions noted in her
file prior to this incident. Supervisor and Staff 1 completed their CPI
restraint training on both 2/16/23 and a refresher on 6/16/23.
Facility Employee Handbook- The employee handbook notes the
following interactions constitute violation of client rights and will not
be tolerated by the agency: “Clients shall not be permitted to
discipline other clients.”
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance with this rule as Staff 1
gave the direction to Youth B to assist with getting a hold of Youth
A prior to Youth A going into a restraint. Staff 1 reported she did
this because she could not catch up to Youth A fast enough and
she was the only staff around.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the current license status be continued.
